entry.title: 丹麦皇冠——学生工体验（更新中）
entry.content:
从 2024 年 5 月到 2025 年 5 月，我在丹麦皇冠 (Danish Crown) 兰讷斯 (Randers) 总部的 Global IT 数据科学小组度过了一段充满成长与趣味的学生工时光。这份工作是如何得来的？详情可见 这篇博文。而本文，我想聊聊那些琐碎却生动的片段，它们拼凑出属于这一年的独特记忆。

初入丹麦皇冠

从奥胡斯搭乘 118 路公交车，一个小时的旅程就将我带到丹麦皇冠位于兰讷斯郊区的总部。这里没有城市的喧嚣，只有大片草坪与蓝天交织成画。远远望去，三栋建筑安静地伫立在广阔的绿野中，仿佛与自然融为一体。初夏的阳光透过窗子洒进办公室，办公桌上的笔记本与屏幕在光影间相映成趣，而窗外，树影婆娑，像是一幅宁静的风景画。

{:height=“50%” width=“50%”}

初到公司的那一天，我在前台完成了拍照与入职手续。小组领导弗朗西斯亲自迎接我。他是个来自西班牙的小个子壮汉，阳光而热情，据我推测，或许是加泰罗尼亚人。接下来的安排显得体贴又随意：他带我去了早餐室，边享用美食边与团队其他成员熟络起来。

{:height=“50%” width=“50%”}

早餐室里，敏捷开发的第一次站会随即展开。我所在的小组堪称国际化：有波兰的菲利普，乌克兰的伊戈尔，还有丹麦的克里斯蒂安。他们个性各异，却都温和友善。初见时的紧张被这些轻松的互动渐渐化解，整个五月我都在适应和学习：了解公司的内部运作，熟悉 Azure 平台，以及试着把自己融入这支多元的团队。

{:height=“50%” width=“50%”}

工作与生活的诗意平衡

在这里，“工作与生活平衡”不仅是一句口号，更是一种深入骨髓的文化。

清晨八点到九点之间，员工陆续上班；下午四点之前，几乎所有人都准时下班。非工作时间无人会以公事打扰，就连“加班”这个词，似乎也是陌生的存在。但这并不意味着松散——在办公时间内，每个人都专注于自己的任务，效率高且富有责任感。

而这种自由也体现在办公形式上：混合办公制度让员工可以自由选择居家或现场工作，完全由个人安排。从未有人过问，也无人干涉。

下班后，站在公交车站等车，看天边晚霞渐渐褪去。那一刻，忙碌的白昼被温柔的黄昏取代，连空气也仿佛变得温润。

{:height=“50%” width=“50%”}

工作中的小插曲

七月因期末考试与暑假，工作暂时搁置；八月重新回归后，我的任务变得更明确。记得有一次，领导弗朗西斯刚布置完新任务，便去休产假了，留下我独立完成。过程虽有些挑战，但完成时的成就感也让我更有信心。

公司食堂的味觉冒险

公司的午餐是自助形式，28 克朗一顿的价格亲民得让人心动。然而，初尝丹麦传统菜式的我，却不得不在心里与“中国胃”妥协。

菜品丰富，主菜常常是热腾腾的肉类，配上些许酱汁。冷盘与沙拉搭配多样，但口味颇有“北欧特色”：比如黑麦面包的粗糙口感让我每次都望而却步，却见同事们抹着黄油吃得津津有味。

而地下冷库则是隐藏的福利宝库：员工可以半价购买冷冻的预制菜，其中的猪肋排成为我的最爱。带回家后抹上糖醋酱，烤上 30 分钟，便是美味的晚餐。

变革的季节

十月，公司迎来了新的 CEO。财务状况的调整伴随着裁员风暴席卷各部门。我们数据科学小组有幸未被波及，但隔壁的 PowerBI 团队就没这么幸运了。

我发现，同事们面对裁员的态度出奇地平静。这种从容源于丹麦社会的高福利制度：失业后只要积极找工作，便能获得足够生活的失业金。这一切，让我重新思考工作的意义与生活的保障。

冬日的温柔时光

冬令时的到来让早晨的阳光来得晚，黄昏的日暮退得早。上班时，踩着湿润的草坪，鼻尖满是泥土的芳香；下班时，落日的余晖染红天际，与归途的车辆交织成冬日的诗篇。这样的生活，简单却丰盈。

entry.title: 丹麦语 DU 3.3 13 Smalltalk i hverdags- og arbejdsliv
entry.content:
Smalltalk i hverdagen

smalltalk eller på dansk småsnak 闲聊

banal -t, -e | -ere, -est 平凡的，平庸的，简单的

overfladisk -, -e 表面的，浅层的

begivenhed -en, -er, -erne 事件

Smalltalk med fremmede

Mange mennesker har svært ved at finde på, hvad de skal sige til mennesker, de møder for første gang.

Udlændinge siger tit, at danskerne ikke er lette at komme i kontakt med, og at de ikke præsenterer dem, de kender, for hinanden. De oplever tit at stå helt alene til en fest, uden nogen taler til dem. I Danmark forventes det, at man “selv gør noget”, det vil sige, at man selv indleder samtaler eller går ind og deltager i andres. 外国人常说丹麦人不容易接触，他们不会互相介绍自己认识的人。他们经常发现自己独自站在聚会上，没有人与他们说话。在丹麦，人们期望你“自己做某事”，也就是说，你自己发起对话或进入并参与他人的对话。

Det kan være svært, hvis man er vant til en anden samtalekultur - eller bare er lidt genert. 如果您习惯了不同的对话文化，或者只是有点害羞，这可能会很困难。

genert -, -e 害羞

Jeg synes, det er …

  • nødvendigt 必要的
  • lige meget 没关系的
  • forkert 错误的
  • problematisk 有问题的
  • udfordrende 有挑战的
  • mærkeligt 奇怪的
  • overraskende 令人惊讶的
  • tåbeligt 愚蠢的

VURDERE, BEGRUNDE OG UDDYBE 评估、论证和解释

  • 我认为某事怎么样，因为如何如何，然后举个例子。

Indledere

Snak om vejr og omgivelser

Hvor er det … (dejligt/dødssygt) vejr.

dødssyg -t, -e 难以忍受的，该死的

Nej, hvor det … (regner/blæser/lyner/sner) …

Det er bare så varmt/koldt i dag.

Det er godt nok en skøn terrasse. 这是一个非常漂亮的露台。

Sikke et stort lokale/en flot udsigt … 房间多大/风景真好……

Sikke det regner/blæser i dag.

Snak om trafik og transport

Har du også haft problemer med trafikken?

Var du også med bussen i dag?

Var dit tog også forsinket i dag?

Hvor var der meget trafik i dag.

Der er godt nok store forsinkelser i dag. 今天可能会有很大的延误。

Snak om maden

Har de noget godt i kantinen i dag?

Hvad er det, du spiser? Er det godt?

Nej, hvor ser det lækkert ud.

Det er godt nok noget lækkert mad.

Snak om arbejde

Nej, hvor er det travlt/stille i dag.

Er det hårdt?

Er det noget at lave i dag?

Enighed og uenighed

Ja, det må du nok sige!

Ja, det må man sige!

Ja, det er helt vidt/voldsomt/ikke så …

Nej, det kan man ikke sige.

Det synes jeg også/ikke.

Det er da ikke så varmt/voldsomt.

Jeg synes ikke, det er så …

Hjælpeverbet får

当强调某个动作的结果而不是动作本身时，可以使用助动词 får + 过去分词 (-t)。

不用管谁执行的动作，不重要（可以是主动，也可以是被动）：

  • 句子中的主语自己做的: Jeg fik afleveret bilen på værkstedet i morges. 我今早把车送到了车间。
  • 主语确保完成某事: Jeg får udskiftet forruden i bilen. 我在车内更换了挡风玻璃。
  • 主语因为该动作受益/受损: Jeg har fået stjålet min iPhone. 我的苹果手机被偷了。

får + 过去分词，动词变位落在 får 上：

不定式：at få -t；现在时：får -t；过去时：fik -t；现在完成时：har fået -t；过去完成时：havde fået gjort

情态动词后：skal have -t

The Existence of Core

Is the core empty?

In the paper, we have proved that Greedy Capture computes 222-core in O(kn)O(kn)O(kn) time for maximum distance loss.

❓Is the 222 the lower bound for code?

Special Case: Binary Distance Value

Consider a graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E), where for every pair i,j∈Vi,j\in Vi,j∈V, (i,j)∈E(i,j)\in E(i,j)∈E if dist(i,j)=1dist(i,j)=1dist(i,j)=1, else dist(i,j)=2dist(i,j)=2dist(i,j)=2.

If there exist a graph such that no matter how we assign the clusters, there always exist a clique of size at least ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉, then the lower bound of 222 is proved.

Split&Merge Algorithm

In any given aforementioned graph GGG, the cluster in the core always exist. (But this can not prove the actual core always exist.)

Consider the algorithm below:

Algorithm Split-and-Merge:

Input: Graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E), kkk

Output: Clustering C=(C1,⋯ ,Ck)C=(C_1,\cdots,C_k)C=(C1​,⋯,Ck​) in the actual core

  1. n←#V,C←∅,X←∅n\gets\#V,C\gets\empty,X\gets\emptyn←#V,C←∅,X←∅
  2. while X≠VX\neq VX=V, do // SPLIT PHASE
    • C′←MAXCLIQUE(V╲X,E)C'\gets MAXCLIQUE(V\diagdown X,E)C′←MAXCLIQUE(V╲X,E)
    • C←C∪{C′}C\gets C\cup\{C'\}C←C∪{C′}
    • X←X∪C′X\gets X\cup C'X←X∪C′
  3. while ∣C∣>k|C|\gt k∣C∣>k, do // MERGE PHASE
    • c1←arg⁡min⁡c∈C∣c∣,c2←arg⁡min⁡c∈C╲{c1}∣c∣,c′=c1∪c2c_1\gets\arg\min_{c\in C}|c|,c_2\gets\arg\min_{c\in C\diagdown\{c_1\}}|c|,c'=c_1\cup c_2c1​←argminc∈C​∣c∣,c2​←argminc∈C╲{c1​}​∣c∣,c′=c1​∪c2​
    • C←C╲{c1,c2},C←C∪{c′}C\gets C\diagdown\{c_1,c_2\},C\gets C\cup \{c'\}C←C╲{c1​,c2​},C←C∪{c′}
  4. return CCC

Analysis of Split&Merge

It’s straightforward to see that Split&Merge is a greedy algorithm.

Since Split&Merge uses MAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUE as an oracle, it is a NP solution.

🎯Theorem: Split-and-Merge always return the cluster in the actual core.

Claim: If a set of points form a cluster, which means, the cost of everybody is 111. All of them have no incentive to form a coalition with anyone outside of the clique.

Thus before merging, any subset of VVV that intersects at least two item-sets in CCC, can not be a clique.

❗By pigeonhole principle, before merging, any item-set in CCC with size already greater than ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉ would not be picked in the merge phase! All data points in these clusters have no incentive to deviate.

In the merge phase, every point who would have been merged have the cost 222. But they can not find other points to form a clique with size at least ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉.

If there exist a clique with size at least ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉ in the merge phase, by pigeonhole principle and the property of maximum clique, it should be chosen in the split phase. Which leads to a contradiction.

🤔Can we extend Split&Merge to more general cases?

Special Case: Trinary Distance Value

Consider a group of points NNN, for every pair of points, their distance can only be 1,2,21,\sqrt2,21,2​,2. (Now matter how the distances are, they always subject to triangle inequality)

If there exists an instance, where no matter how we assign kkk clusters, the approximation of core cannot be better than 2\sqrt22​, then we prove that the bound for inapproximability of core is 2\sqrt22​.

It seems that we can extend Split&Merge in this case to produce clustering in the core.

Extend Split&Merge for Trinary Distance Value

The extended version of Split&Merge:

Input: kkk and the distance between each pair of points

  1. construct a graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E), where VVV corresponds to the set of data points. For a pair i,j∈Vi,j\in Vi,j∈V, there is an edge (i,j)∈E(i,j)\in E(i,j)∈E if the distance between iii and jjj is 111.
  2. X←V,C←∅X\gets V,C\gets\emptyX←V,C←∅
  3. c←MAXCLIQUE(X,E)c\gets MAXCLIQUE(X,E)c←MAXCLIQUE(X,E)
  4. while ∣c∣≥⌈n/k⌉|c|\ge\lceil n/k\rceil∣c∣≥⌈n/k⌉ do // find the clique of distance 111 with large enough size
    • C←C∪{c}C\gets C\cup\{c\}C←C∪{c}
    • X←X╲cX\gets X\diagdown cX←X╲c
    • c←MAXCLIQUE(X,E)c\gets MAXCLIQUE(X,E)c←MAXCLIQUE(X,E)
  5. construct a graph G′=(X,E)G'=(X,E)G′=(X,E), where XXX corresponds to the free data points. For a pair i,j∈Vi,j\in Vi,j∈V, there is an edge (i,j)∈E(i,j)\in E(i,j)∈E if the distance between iii and jjj is either 111 or 2\sqrt22​
  6. C′←C'\getsC′←Split&Merge(G′,k−∣C∣)(G',k-|C|)(G′,k−∣C∣) // run Split&Merge on remaining points
  7. C←C∪C′C\gets C\cup C'C←C∪C′
  8. return CCC

Analysis Split&Merge for Trinary Case

For simplicity, we introduce the notation of core-violator: A core-violator is a subset S⊆NS\subseteq NS⊆N with size ≥⌈n/k⌉\ge\lceil n/k\rceil≥⌈n/k⌉, where each point in SSS has a strictly better cost if they are clustered together.

🤔Claim: extended version of Split&Merge always return a clustering in the core.

Assume that Split&Merge returns a clustering not in the core. Which means there exist a core-violator SSS.

  • Since the minimal distance is 111 and the cost of each points in the clique in CCC is exactly 111 before Split&Merge, core-violator can’t exist there.

  • The only possible existence of core-violator is in the Split&Merge step.

    • Claim: It is not possible that the a free point at step 5 can collude with any point in the clique formed in step 4.
    • The only possible core-violator can formed only among free points at step 5.
    • ❗️By the property of step 4, any subset of free points at step 5 can not form a core-violator with distance 111 between any pair. Otherwise they they should be clustered in step 4.
      • Thus, the possible core-violator must contain a free point improving cost from 222 to 2\sqrt22​, meaning that there exist a large enough clique in G′G'G′ after the merge phase.
      • By pigeonhole principle, this contradicts the property of split phase (This large enough clique must be chosen in split phase).

Thus the extended version of Split&Merge guarantees the core property.

❓Can we further extend Split&Merge to general cases where there are n(n−1)/2n(n-1)/2n(n−1)/2 distances?

The answer is YES if I can successfully extend splir&merge to general cases

Extend Split&Merge to General Cases

For nnn data points in a metric space, given number of clusters kkk.

We construct the complete weighted undirected graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E) where VVV corresponds to the set of data points, for each pair (i,j)∈E(i,j)\in E(i,j)∈E, the weight is the distance between iii and jjj. There are n(n−1)/2n(n-1)/2n(n−1)/2 edges in GGG.

First, we sort the edges by weight.

Start from another graph with VVV and no edge. We iteratively add an edge from the scratch in the ascending order.

  • At each time, we check whether there exist a clique of size at least ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉.
    • If so, we immediately include them into a cluster and delete them temporarily.

🤔Intuitively I think this extension outputs a cluster in the core. But I haven’t well organized a formal proof.

entry.content:
Tekstsammenhæng i jobansøgninger

På dansk har vi mulighed for at variere sætningsspidserne.

Dvs. at mange andre led en subjektet kan stå først i sætningen.

For eks.

  1. Jeg vil gerne bruge min fritid på at hjælpe andre. Jeg kan samtidig selv få mulighed for at træne mit dansk.
  2. Min fritid vil jeg gerne bruge på at hjælpe andre. Samtidig kan jeg selv få mulighed for at træne mit dansk.

Tekst 2. har bedre sammenhængen.

不要老是写主谓宾的句子，这样太无聊了。需要变换一下语序，为了强调把其他成分放到第一位，然后动词第二位。

Den danske model

forforståelse -n, -r, -rne 先入为主；偏见

velfærdsstat -en, -er, -erne 福利国家

overenskomst -en, -er, -erne 协议；合同

Den danske model - 3 grunde

  1. Det et en god forretning for Danmark.
  2. Det er med til at skrive en lav grad af økonomisk ulighed.
  3. Det har sikret et lavt konflikt niveau i Danmark.

Flexicurity

Den danske model = flexicurity (fleksibilitet + sikkerhed)

  • Systemet er fleksibelt for arbejdsgiverne, fordi de nemt kan både hyre og fyre. 用人单位雇佣和解雇人很容易。
  • Samtidig giver systemet en vis økonomisk sikkerhed for arbejdstagerne. 就业人员有保障。

Overenskomster

I Danmark er arbejdstagere og arbejdsgivere, der bestemmer løn- og arbejdsforhold. 在丹麦由雇主和雇员谈判决定薪资和工作条件。

Overenskomsterne bygger på dialog, samarbejde og respekt mellem de to parter, og de varer fra to til fire år. 集体协议的有效期为两到四年。

En 100 år gammel tradition

nem og fredelig 轻松和平

urolig og ustabil 动荡不安

hovedaftale 主要协议

principper 原则

som stadig gælder i dag. 至今仍然适用。

ret til at + inf. 做某事的权利

‘Septemberforliget’ 九月协议

Fagforeninger og A-kasser

APSP

All-Pairs Shortest Paths (APSP) problem: Given an nnn node graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E), and integer edge weights w:E→{−M,⋯ ,M}w:E\to\{-M,\cdots,M\}w:E→{−M,⋯,M} for some M=nO(1)M=n^{O(1)}M=nO(1), compute for every u,v∈Vu,v\in Vu,v∈V, the shortest path distance d(u,v)d(u,v)d(u,v) in GGG from uuu to vvv. Assume that GGG does not contain negative weight cycles.

求所有点的最短路径，有经典弗洛伊德算法啊。

Floyd-Warshall algorithm can solve APSP in O(n3)O(n^3)O(n3). One can run Dijkstra’s algorithm from every vertex using some tricks, SOTA is n3/exp⁡(log⁡n)n^3/\exp(\sqrt{\log n})n3/exp(logn​).

APSP Hypothesis. No randomized algorithm can solve APSP in O(n3−ϵ)O(n^{3-\epsilon})O(n3−ϵ) time for ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0 on nnn node graphs with edge weights in {−nc,⋯ ,nc}\{-n^c,\cdots,n^c\}{−nc,⋯,nc} and no negative cycles for large enough ccc.

Fine-grained Reductions

Consider problem AAA with textbook runtime a(n)a(n)a(n) and problem BBB with text book runtime b(n)b(n)b(n). Given a supposed O(b(n)1−ϵ)O(b(n)^{1-\epsilon})O(b(n)1−ϵ) time algorithm for BBB for ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0, we would like to compose it with another algorithm that transforms instances of AAA into instances of BBB, to obtain an algorithm for AAA running in time O(a(n)1−ϵ′)O(a(n)^{1-\epsilon'})O(a(n)1−ϵ′) time for ϵ′>0\epsilon'\gt0ϵ′>0 being a function of ϵ\epsilonϵ.

📖Definition of fine-grained reduction. Assume that AAA and BBB are computational problems and a(n)a(n)a(n) and b(n)b(n)b(n) are their conjectured running time lower bounds, respectively. We say AAA (a,b)(a,b)(a,b)-reduces to BBB (A≤a,bBA\le_{a,b}BA≤a,b​B), if for every ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0, there exists δ>0\delta\gt0δ>0, and an algorithm RRR for AAA that runs in time (a(n))1−δ(a(n))^{1-\delta}(a(n))1−δ on inputs of length nnn, making qqq calls to an oracle for BBB with query lengths n1,⋯ ,nqn_1,\cdots,n_qn1​,⋯,nq​, where

∑i=1q(b(ni))1−ϵ≤(a(n))1−δ.\sum_{i=1}^q(b(n_i))^{1-\epsilon}\le(a(n))^{1-\delta}.i=1∑q​(b(ni​))1−ϵ≤(a(n))1−δ.

If A≤a,bBA\le_{a,b}BA≤a,b​B and B≤a,bAB\le_{a,b}AB≤a,b​A, we say that AAA and BBB are fine-grained equivalent, A≡a,bBA\equiv_{a,b}BA≡a,b​B.

若存在一个能在指数位置上打破 AAA 问题猜想时间复杂度下界的算法 RRR，并且该算法包含若干次调用在指数位置上打破 BBB 问题猜想复杂度下界的算法，则称 AAA 能细粒度归约到 BBB。

被绕晕了没有？

The definition implies that if A≤a,bBA\le_{a,b}BA≤a,b​B and BBB has an algorithm with running time O(b(n))1−ϵO(b(n))^{1-\epsilon}O(b(n))1−ϵ, then AAA can be solved by replacing the oracle calls by corresponding runs of the algorithm, obtaining a runtime of O(a(n)1−δ)O(a(n)^{1-\delta})O(a(n)1−δ) for AAA for some δ>0\delta\gt0δ>0.

If A≡a,bBA\equiv_{a,b}BA≡a,b​B, then we can not be able to improve a(n)a(n)a(n) and b(n)b(n)b(n) for AAA and BBB respectively, is the same.

Hardness from SETH

Orthogonal Vectors (OV) problem requires quadratic time under SETH.

OV problem: Let d=ω(log⁡n)d=\omega(\log n)d=ω(logn); given two sets A,B⊆{0,1}dA,B\subseteq\{0,1\}^dA,B⊆{0,1}d with ∣A∣=∣B∣=n|A|=|B|=n∣A∣=∣B∣=n, determine whether there exist a∈A,b∈Ba\in A,b\in Ba∈A,b∈B s.t. a⋅b=0a\cdot b=0a⋅b=0 where a⋅b=∑i=1da[i]]⋅b[i]a\cdot b=\sum_{i=1}^da[i]]\cdot b[i]a⋅b=∑i=1d​a[i]]⋅b[i].

kkk-OV problem for constant k≥2k\ge2k≥2: Let d=ω(log⁡n)d=\omega(\log n)d=ω(logn); given kkk sets A1,⋯ ,Ak⊆{0,1}dA_1,\cdots,A_k\subseteq\{0,1\}^dA1​,⋯,Ak​⊆{0,1}d with ∣Ai∣=n|A_i|=n∣Ai​∣=n for all iii, determine whether there exist a1∈A1,⋯ ,ak∈Aka_1\in A_1,\cdots,a_k\in A_ka1​∈A1​,⋯,ak​∈Ak​ s.t. a1⋅...⋅ak=0a_1\cdot...\cdot a_k=0a1​⋅...⋅ak​=0 where a1⋅...⋅ak=∑i=1d∏j=1kaj[i]a_1\cdot...\cdot a_k=\sum_{i=1}^d\prod_{j=1}^ka_j[i]a1​⋅...⋅ak​=∑i=1d​∏j=1k​aj​[i].

kkk-OV can be solved in O(nkd)O(n^kd)O(nkd) time by exhaustive search, for any k≥2k\ge2k≥2. SOTA: nk−1/Θ(log⁡(d/log⁡n))n^{k-1/\Theta(\log(d/\log n))}nk−1/Θ(log(d/logn)). It seems that nk−o(1)n^{k-o(1)}nk−o(1) is necessary.

kkk-OV Hypothesis: No randomized algorithm can solve kkk-OV on instance of size nnn in nk−ϵdO(1)n^{k-\epsilon}d^{O(1)}nk−ϵdO(1) time for constant ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0.

kOV to CNF-SAT

🎯Theorem of reduction from kkk-OV to CNF−SATCNF-SATCNF−SAT: If kkk-OV on sets with NNN vectors from {0,1}m\{0,1\}^m{0,1}m can be solved in Nk−ϵmO(1)N^{k-\epsilon}m^{O(1)}Nk−ϵmO(1) time for any ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0, then CNT−SATCNT-SATCNT−SAT on nnn variables and mmm clauses can be solved in 2(1−ϵ′)nmO(1)2^{(1-\epsilon')n}m^{O(1)}2(1−ϵ′)nmO(1) time for some ϵ′>0\epsilon'\gt0ϵ′>0 and SETH is false.

kOV to Diameter probelm

kkk-OV can also do fine-grained reduction to diameter problem.

图的直径：图中所有点对中的最长距离

🎯Theorem of reduction from kkk-OV to Diameter problem. If one can distinguish between diameter 222 and 333 in an undirected unweighted graph with O(N)O(N)O(N) nodes and edges in O(N2−ϵ)O(N^{2-\epsilon})O(N2−ϵ) time for some ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0, then 222-OV on two sets of nnn vectors in ddd dimensions can be solved in n2−ϵdO(1)n^{2-\epsilon}d^{O(1)}n2−ϵdO(1) time and SETH is false.

Parameterized Complexity

Proposed by Rod Downey, Victoria University, New Zealand

Parameterized complexity:

  1. The input to the problem.
  2. The aspects of the input that constitute the parameter.
  3. The question.

A parameterized language is L⊆Σ∗×Σ∗L\subseteq\Sigma^*\times\Sigma^*L⊆Σ∗×Σ∗ where we refer to the second coordinate as parameter.

For simplicity, we can think of L⊆Σ∗×NL\subseteq\Sigma^*\times \NL⊆Σ∗×N.

📖Definition of FPT. A parameterized language LLL is fixed parameter tractable (FPT), iff there is a computable function fff, a constant ccc, and a deterministic algorithm MMM s.t.

∀x,k:⟨x,k⟩∈L⇔M(x,k) accepts,\forall x,k:\lang x,k\rang\in L\Lrarr M(x,k)\text{ accepts},∀x,k:⟨x,k⟩∈L⇔M(x,k) accepts,

and the running time of M(x,k)M(x,k)M(x,k) is ≤f(k)∣x∣c\le f(k)|x|^c≤f(k)∣x∣c.

It’s not hard to see that f(k)∣x∣c=O(∣x∣c)+f(k)f(k)|x|^c=O(|x|^c)+f(k)f(k)∣x∣c=O(∣x∣c)+f(k) for some computable fff.

Example: a parameterized version of Vertex Cover problem:

  • Instance: A graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E).
  • Parameter: A positive integer kkk.
  • Question: Does GGG have a vertex cover of size ≤k\le k≤k?

There is an algorithm running in time O(1.2738k+kn)O(1.2738^k+kn)O(1.2738k+kn).

So in this problem, we have f(k)=1.2738kf(k)=1.2738^kf(k)=1.2738k. Introduce O∗O^*O∗ notation which ignores f(k)f(k)f(k) be it additive or multiplicative and is only concerned with the exponential part. Thus the algorithm is O∗(n1)O^*(n^1)O∗(n1).

Bounded Search Trees

Some optimized methods.

Kernelization

📖Definition of Kernelization. Let L⊆Σ∗×Σ∗L\subseteq\Sigma^*\times\Sigma^*L⊆Σ∗×Σ∗ be a parameterized language. A reduction to a problem kernel, or kernelization, comprises replacing an instance (I,k)(I,k)(I,k) by a reduced instance (I′,k′)(I',k')(I′,k′), called a problem kernel, such that

  1. k′≤kk'\le kk′≤k
  2. ∣I′∣≤g(k)|I'|\le g(k)∣I′∣≤g(k), for some function ggg depending only on kkk.
  3. (I,k)∈L⇔(I′,k′)∈L(I,k)\in L\Lrarr(I',k')\in L(I,k)∈L⇔(I′,k′)∈L.

The reduction from (I,k)(I,k)(I,k) to (I′,k′)(I',k')(I′,k′) must be computable in time polynomial in ∣I∣+∣k∣|I|+|k|∣I∣+∣k∣.

Reduction rules for a kernel for Vertex Cover:

  1. Remove all isolated vertices.
  2. For any degree one vertex vvv, add its single neighbor uuu to the solution set and remove uuu and all of its incident edges from the graph.
  3. If there is a vertex vvv of degree at least k+1k+1k+1, add vvv to the solution set and remove vvv and all of its neighbors.

After applying these rules, we get to a graph (G′,k′)(G',k')(G′,k′), where no vertex in the reduced graph has degree greater than k′≤kk'\le kk′≤k, or less than two. Then simple combinatorics shows that if such a reduced graph has a size kkk vertex cover, its must have size ≤k2\le k^2≤k2. This is the size k2k^2k2 kernelization.

Lower bounds for some W[1]-hard Problems

Chen et.al.: “Tight lower bounds for certain parameterized NP-hard problems” (original paper), Section 4.

The class SNPSNPSNP contains many NPNPNP-hard problems including qqq-SAT, qqq-Colorability, qqq-Set Cover, Vertex Cover, and Independent Set.

It is commonly believed that it is unlikely that all problems in SNPSNPSNP are solvable in sub-exponential time.

🎯Theorem (Vertex Cover reduction has lower bound). Given an instance (G,k)(G,k)(G,k) of Vertex Cover, there is a polynomial time algorithm which either reports that GGG doesn’t have a vertex cover of size kkk, or produces a subgraph G′G'G′ of GGG with at most 2k′2k'2k′ vertices, where k′≤kk'\le kk′≤k, such that GGG has a vertex cover of size kkk iff G′G'G′ has a vertex cover of size k′k'k′.

🎯Theorem of Independent set poly-time solvable hypothesis. If the parameterized Independent Set problem can be solved in time nO(k)n^{O(k)}nO(k), where nnn is the number of vertices in the graph, then all problems in SNPSNPSNP can be solved in sub-exponential time.

🎯Theorem of clique poly-time solvable hypothesis. If Clique, Weight qqq-SAT, Dominating Set, Dominating Clique, or Graph kkk-Cut can be solved in time nO(k)n^{O(k)}nO(k) then all the problems in SNPSNPSNP can be solved in sub-exponential time, where nnn is the size of the universal set from which the kkk elements are to be selected.

entry.content:
Tekst-struktur i jobansøgning

写求职信，是 DU 3.3 的一大考点。

Hovedoverskrift, der fortæller. Hvilken stilling, du søger. 标题写清楚要找什么职位

F.eks. Ansøgning om stilling som kok på restaurant ‘Blixen’

  • Vælg en overskrift med kompetencer, der matcher firmaets behov.

Boolean satisfiability is prototypical NPNPNP-complete problem.

There is no algorithm deciding SATSATSAT in worst case in polynomial time unless P=NPP=NPP=NP.

We always assume that P≠NPP\neq NPP=NP.

For SATSATSAT problem, SOTA algorithm uses time 2(1−1O(log⁡(m/n)))nmO(1)2^{(1-\frac{1}{O(\log(m/n))})n}m^{O(1)}2(1−O(log(m/n))1​)nmO(1).

For special case of kSATkSATkSAT, there are faster algorithms, but all take time 2(1−ck)n2^{(1-\frac{c}{k})n}2(1−kc​)n for some constant 0<c<k0\lt c\lt k0<c<k.

Schöning’s kSAT Algorithm

该算法在上学期随机算法课最后一节课 马尔可夫链和随机游走 中讲过，故此处略过。

分析过程很恶心。

The Sparsification Lemma

🎯Lemma 22. For all ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0 and integers kkk, there exists a constant C=C(ϵ,k)C=C(\epsilon,k)C=C(ϵ,k) and an algorithm that given as input a kCNFkCNFkCNF Φ\PhiΦ in nnn variables runs in time tnO(1)tn^{O(1)}tnO(1), where t≤2ϵnt\le2^{\epsilon n}t≤2ϵn, and give as output a list of kCNFkCNFkCNF formulas Ψ1,⋯ ,Ψt\Psi_1,\cdots,\Psi_tΨ1​,⋯,Ψt​ each with at most CnCnCn clauses such that

Φ(x)=⋁i=1tΨi(x),\Phi(x)=\bigvee_{i=1}^t\Psi_i(x),Φ(x)=i=1⋁t​Ψi​(x),

for all x∈{0,1}nx\in\{0,1\}^nx∈{0,1}n.

Reduce to Hitting Set Problem

Recall HittingSetHittingSetHittingSet problem. Consider a universe UUU of elements and a collection S\mathcal SS of subsets of U\mathcal UU. We say that T⊆UT\subseteq\mathcal UT⊆U is a hitting set for S\mathcal SS if S∩T≠∅S\cap T\neq\emptyS∩T=∅ for all S∈SS\in\mathcal SS∈S. We denote by σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal S)σ(S) the collection of all hitting sets of S\mathcal SS.

kHittingSetkHittingSetkHittingSet problem:

  • Instance: Collection S\mathcal SS of subsets of a universe U=2U\mathcal U=2^UU=2U.
  • Output: Hitting set TTT for S\mathcal SS minimizing ∣T∣|T|∣T∣.

We denote by kHittingSetkHittingSetkHittingSet the restriction to collections of subsets of size at most kkk.

We can transform kSATkSATkSAT into kHittingSetkHittingSetkHittingSet problem:

  • C\mathcal CC is the subsets of U\mathcal UU corresponding to the clauses of Φ\PhiΦ.
  • An assignment to the variables of Φ\PhiΦ can be viewed as a subset of U\mathcal UU.
  • A\mathcal AA is the collection of the nnn sets {xi,xi‾}\{x_i,\overline{x_i}\}{xi​,xi​​} for i=1,⋯ ,ni=1,\cdots,ni=1,⋯,n. Note that assignments to the variables of Φ\PhiΦ are in one-to-one correspondence to hitting sets of A\mathcal AA.
  • Defining SΦ=C∪A\mathcal S_\Phi=\mathcal C\cup\mathcal ASΦ​=C∪A

Observation: There is a one-to-one correspondence between the set of satisfying assignments of Φ\PhiΦ and hitting sets of SΦ\mathcal S_\PhiSΦ​ of size nnn.

Any collection of subsets T\mathcal TT over U\mathcal UU can be viewed as a CNF formula by letting each subset define a clause.

📖Definition 57. Let T\mathcal TT and S\mathcal SS be collections of subsets. We say that T\mathcal TT is a restriction of S\mathcal SS if for every S∈SS\in\mathcal SS∈S there exists T∈TT\in\mathcal TT∈T s.t. T⊆ST\subseteq ST⊆S.

也就是集合的集合 S\mathcal SS 中的每一个元素（是一个集合）是集合的集合 T\mathcal TT 中对应有一个元素（是一个集合）的子集。

很绕，不是吗？

Clearly, if T\mathcal TT is a restriction of S\mathcal SS, then σ(T)⊆σ(S)\sigma(\mathcal T)\subseteq\sigma(\mathcal S)σ(T)⊆σ(S). Any satisfying assignment of CNF formula given by T\mathcal TT is also a satisfying assignment of the CNF formula given by S\mathcal SS.

🤔Lemma 23 (Hitting set correspondence). For all ϵ>0\epsilon\gt0ϵ>0 and integers kkk, there exists a constant C=C(ϵ,k)C=C(\epsilon,k)C=C(ϵ,k) and an algorithm that given as input collection S\mathcal SS of subsets of size at most kkk of a universe U\mathcal UU of size nnn runs in time tnO(1)tn^{O(1)}tnO(1), where t≤2ϵnt\le 2^{\epsilon n}t≤2ϵn, and give as output a list of restrictions T1,⋯ ,Tt\mathcal T_1,\cdots,\mathcal T_tT1​,⋯,Tt​ each with at most CnCnCn subsets of U\mathcal UU which are all of size at most kkk s.t.

σ(S)=⋃i=1tσ(Ti).\sigma(\mathcal S)=\bigcup_{i=1}^t\sigma(\mathcal T_i).σ(S)=i=1⋃t​σ(Ti​).

We call a subset of U\mathcal UU of size jjj: jjj-set.

The algorithm is a branching algorithm where each leaf of the recursion tree will give a restriction of S\mathcal SS.

To branch, the algorithm looks for a large collection of subsets of the same size that has a non-empty intersection, and branches on whether or not the common intersection will be hit by the hitting set. We define such collections of sets as flowers.

📖Definition 58. Let S1,⋯ ,ScS_1,\cdots,S_cS1​,⋯,Sc​ be jjj-sets.

  • We say that these sets are a flower if H=⋂i=1cSi≠∅H=\bigcap_{i=1}^cS_i\neq\emptyH=⋂i=1c​Si​=∅.
  • We call HHH the heart of the flower and sets (S1╲H),⋯ ,(Sc╲H)(S_1\diagdown H),\cdots,(S_c\diagdown H)(S1​╲H),⋯,(Sc​╲H) the petals.
  • Note that all petals have the same size j−∣H∣j-|H|j−∣H∣, which we denote as petal-size.

定义一朵花：一组大小为 jjj 的集合，它们的交集为空。

花心：这组集合的交集。对应定义花心的大小。

花瓣：每个集合去除花心。对应定义花瓣的大小。

The algorithm will be controlled by integer parameters 2=θ0<θ1<⋯<θk−12=\theta_0\lt\theta_1\lt\cdots\lt\theta_{k-1}2=θ0​<θ1​<⋯<θk−1​. We make θi\theta_iθi​ increase rapidly as a parameter of iii.

📖Definition 59. Let S1,⋯ ,ScS_1,\cdots,S_cS1​,⋯,Sc​ be a flower of jjj-sets and petal-size iii.

  • The flower is large if c≥θic\ge\theta_ic≥θi​.
  • The flower is good if
    • it is a large flower chosen s.t. jjj is chosen minimally
    • and if more than one large flower of jjj-sets exists then chosen s.t. iii is chosen minimally.

如果一朵花含有集合的个数足够大，则称这朵花是“大”的。

如果一朵花是“大”的，并且其中包含的集合大小、花瓣大小都是最小的，则称这朵花是“好”的。

很形象的定义，但还是很绕

The algorithm will eliminate sets of a collection T\mathcal TT that contain other sets of the collection. If S,T∈TS,T\in\mathcal TS,T∈T are such that S⊊TS\subsetneq TS⊊T, we say that TTT is eliminated by SSS.

Let π(T)\pi(\mathcal T)π(T) denote the collection of minimal sets of T\mathcal TT, i.e., the sets of T\mathcal TT that are not eliminated by sets of T\mathcal TT.

Pseudo code of Reduce Algorithm

Reduce(S)(\mathcal S)(S)

Input: Collection S\mathcal SS of subsets of size at most kkk of a universe U\mathcal UU.

Output: Restrictions T1,⋯ ,Tt\mathcal T_1,\cdots,\mathcal T_tT1​,⋯,Tt​ of s.t. σ(S)=⋃i=1tσ(Ti)\sigma(\mathcal S)=\bigcup_{i=1}^t\sigma(\mathcal T_i)σ(S)=⋃i=1t​σ(Ti​).

  1. S←π(S)\mathcal S\gets\pi(\mathcal S)S←π(S).

In this post, we focus on upper and lower bound of core where non-clusterings are.

Let the loss (or cost) function for every data points be maximum distance between any other points and itself:

We have known that a clustering in the exact core must exist given N,kN,kN,k.

For the approximation of core: The Greedy Capture algorithm computes the upper bound of 222 in polynomial time. And it have the lower bound of 111.

What about the gap between 1 and 2???

There are some open problems and I am trying to answer.

Complexity for Auditing the Core

❓What is the time complexity for verifying whether a given clustering is in the exact core?

TL;DR It is a NP-hard problem.

The analysis of verifying problem:

We need to check if any subset S⊆VS\subseteq VS⊆V with ∣S∣≥⌈n/k⌉|S|\ge\lceil n/k\rceil∣S∣≥⌈n/k⌉ can form a cluster such that the maximum distance between any two points in SSS is less than each agent’s maximum distance to others in its current cluster. If such a subset exists, then the clustering violates the core property.

Consider a reduction from another NP-complete problem MAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUE. The problem asks if there is a clique of a specified size in an undirected graph G=(V,E)G=(V,E)G=(V,E).

Problem Setup: We have an undirected graph G=(V,E)G = (V, E)G=(V,E) with nnn vertices. We need to decide if a given clustering is in the core, with each data point’s cost being the maximum distance between itself and all other points in the same cluster.

Constructing the Graph: To reduce MAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUE to our core-checking problem, we will build a graph with the properties:

  • For every edge (i,j)∈E(i,j)\in E(i,j)∈E, the distance d(i,j)d(i, j)d(i,j) is less than
    1. the maximum distance between iii and all other points in iii’s cluster
    2. the maximum distance between jjj and all other points in jjj’s cluster.

Formulating the Core Condition in Terms of MAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUEMAXCLIQUE: If a cluster is in the core, no subset SSS of data points, with ∣S∣≥⌈nk⌉|S| \geq\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil∣S∣≥⌈kn​⌉, can improve their maximum distance cost by clustering together. If we interpret each cluster as requiring a subset of nodes that are all pairwise connected (thus forming a clique), we can state the core problem as follows:

  • Determine if there exists a subset of nodes of size at least ⌈nk⌉\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil⌈kn​⌉ such that every pair of nodes in it are connected.
  • This requires identifying the largest clique in GGG and checking if it can be at least as large as ⌈nk⌉\lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil⌈kn​⌉, which directly maps to finding the maximum clique.

Verifying Core Membership: To verify if a clustering is in the core using this construction, we would:

  • Check if there exists a subset S⊆VS \subseteq VS⊆V with ∣S∣≥⌈nk⌉|S| \geq \lceil\frac{n}{k}\rceil∣S∣≥⌈kn​⌉ such that all nodes in SSS have edges to each other (i.e., a clique).
  • If such a subset SSS exists, it would imply that these nodes could deviate by forming their own cluster with a smaller maximum distance, violating the core property.
  • Thus, solving this for all clusters to determine if the clustering as a whole satisfies the core property would require us to solve a clique-finding problem.

Completing the NP-Hardness Reduction: Since finding a maximum clique is NP-hard, and since verifying the core property requires solving the maximum clique problem to check for the presence of sufficiently large cliques in each cluster, the problem of deciding if a clustering is in the core is NP-hard.

entry.content:
What is heur?

By default, heur is set to binomial.

So I plug in some time measure on several parts of binomial.

It seems that the two sampling parts (generating negative sample for head and tail respectively) take most of running time.

So I consider working on optimization for sampling.

Next we need a more fine-grained profiling with sampling loop!

Optimization on Sampling

It seems that random.choice takes some time.

More importantly, in while loop, there exist if branch, which is the bottle-neck.

We need to break these.

So we adapt to another sampling approach:

  1. Generating random permutation for entity id and relation id, respectively.
  2. Use torch.stack to make up sampling triple without checking its negativity.
  3. Use some parallelization methods to calculate relative complement set.

Then we have a sample that contains only negative triples.

Experiment Results

Raw Implementation

Dataset Countries

python experiment_controller.py -d Countries -e TransE -t ReliK

Total running time: 538 seconds

Dataset CodexSmall

nohup python experiment_controller.py -d CodexSmall -e TransE -t ReliK > SEQ_raw_codexsmall.log 2>&1 &

Optimized Sampling

Dataset CodexSmall

In Countries dataset, we see the general time is worse off.

entry.content:
More precise model

Problem of integer multiplication.

Registers can contain arbitrary integers. Consider repeated squaring to number 222. After just nnn multiplications, the resulting number is 22n2^{2^n}22n, a doubly exponential large number in nnn. This requires exponential number of bits.

A RAM has an infinite sequence of registers each able to contain an arbitrary non-negative integer.

  • Machine is controlled by a program consisting of a list of instructions.
  • Registers can be added or subtracted.
  • Contents of a register can be stored or retrieved in a second register by means of indirect addressing using a third register.
  • Execution can be controlled by conditional jumps in the list of instructions.

The cost for using a register containing the integer nnn is given by a cost function ℓ(n)\ell(n)ℓ(n).

  • Having ℓ(n)=1\ell(n)=1ℓ(n)=1 gives the unit-cost RAM
  • Having ℓ(n)=⌈log⁡2(n+1)⌉\ell(n)=\lceil\log_2(n+1)\rceilℓ(n)=⌈log2​(n+1)⌉ gives the logarithmic-cost RAM.

Don’t include multiplication as a basic operation in this model.

The RAM and the Turing machine models of computation can simulate each other with only a logarithmic factor.

The word RAM model refines the integer RAM by bounding the magnitude of the numbers that can be stored in a single register, and having unit cost operations on these.

This is formally done by introducing a parameter www, called the word-size, and having each register can store an element of {0,1}w\{0,1\}^w{0,1}w.

The word size www will increase with the length of the input nnn, and in particular we have w=Ω(log⁡n)w=\Omega(\log n)w=Ω(logn) to be able to perform indirectly random access to the entire input.

The basic set of instructions, gives restricted word RAM, consists of addition, subtraction, left and right shifts, and bit-wise AND, OR, NOT.

A common extension is to include integer multiplication as a unit cost operation.

Another extension is exclude integer multiplication but allow all functions computable by AC0AC^0AC0 circuits of polynomial size in www, thus giving the AC0AC^0AC0 word RAM.

The typical setting of the word size, known as the trans-dichotomous setting, is to have w=Θ(log⁡n)w=\Theta(\log n)w=Θ(logn).

Some Algorithms requires a larger word size.

A notable example is the task of sorting nnn integers. When w=Ω(log⁡2+ϵn)w=\Omega(\log^{2+\epsilon}n)w=Ω(log2+ϵn) a randomized algorithm using expected time O(n)O(n)O(n) exists.

The best known algorithm that works for all word sizes, uses O(nlog⁡log⁡n)O(n\sqrt{\log\log n})O(nloglogn​) time.

Question:

  2. Do the algorithms for centroid clustering also work for non-centroid one?
  3. Can we audit the PROP of a given algorithm?

Each agent iii has a loss function ℓi\ell_iℓi​, the loss under clustering CCC is ℓi(C(i))\ell_i(C(i))ℓi​(C(i)). C(i)C(i)C(i) denotes the cluster containing her.

  • ℓi\ell_iℓi​ can be distance

Summary of results

FJR as a relaxation of the core. This paper propose GreedyCohesiveClustering, which is an adaptation of Greedy Cohesive Rule from social choice theory.

Related Work

PROP by Chen et al.

PROP revisit by Micha and Shah

FJR in centroid clustering by Aziz et al.

Model

[t]={1,⋯ ,t}[t]=\{1,\cdots,t\}[t]={1,⋯,t} for t∈Nt\in\Nt∈N. Given a set NNN of nnn agents, and the desired number of clusters kkk.

Each agent i∈Ni\in Ni∈N has an associated loss function ℓi:2N╲2N╲i→R≥0\ell_i:2^N\diagdown2^{N\diagdown i}\to\R_{\ge0}ℓi​:2N╲2N╲i→R≥0​, where ℓi(S)\ell_i(S)ℓi​(S) is the cost to agent iii for being part of group SSS. A kkk-clustering C=(C1,⋯ ,Ck)C=(C_1,\cdots,C_k)C=(C1​,⋯,Ck​) is a partition of NNN into kkk clusters, where Ct∩Ct′=∅C_t\cap C_{t'}=\emptyCt​∩Ct′​=∅ for t≠t′t\neq t't=t′ and ∪t=1kCt=N\cup_{t=1}^kC_t=N∪t=1k​Ct​=N. For simplicity, C(i)C(i)C(i) is the cluster containing iii.

The loss of iii is ℓi(C(i))\ell_i(C(i))ℓi​(C(i)).

Loss function

  • A distance metric over NNN is given by d:N×N→R≥0d:N\times N\to\R_{\ge0}d:N×N→R≥0​, which satisfies normality, symmetry and triangle inequality.
  • Arbitrary losses. The loss ℓi(S)\ell_i(S)ℓi​(S) is arbitrary non-negative number for each agent i∈Ni\in Ni∈N and cluster S∋iS\ni iS∋i.
  • Average loss. Given a distance metric ddd over NNN, ℓi(S)=1∣S∣∑j∈Sd(i,j)\ell_i(S)=\frac{1}{|S|}\sum_{j\in S}d(i,j)ℓi​(S)=∣S∣1​∑j∈S​d(i,j) for each agent i∈Ni\in Ni∈N and cluster S∋iS\ni iS∋i. Agent iii prefers the agents in her cluster to be close to her on average.
  • Maximum loss. Given a distance metric ddd, ℓi(S)=max⁡j∈Sd(i,j)\ell_i(S)=\max_{j\in S}d(i,j)ℓi​(S)=maxj∈S​d(i,j). Agent iii prefers that no agent in her cluster to be too far from her.

Core

If no group of agents S⊆NS\subseteq NS⊆N can choose another outcome that

  1. They are entitled to choose based on their proportion of the whole population ∣S∣/∣N∣|S|/|N|∣S∣/∣N∣
  2. Every member of group SSS is happier

📖Definition 1 (α\alphaα-Core). For α≥1\alpha\ge1α≥1, a kkk-clustering C=(C1,⋯ ,Ck)C=(C_1,\cdots,C_k)C=(C1​,⋯,Ck​) is said to be in the α\alphaα-core if there is no group of agents S⊆NS\subseteq NS⊆N with ∣S∣≥n/k|S|\ge n/k∣S∣≥n/k s.t. α⋅ℓi(S)<ℓi(C(i))\alpha\cdot\ell_i(S)\lt\ell_i(C(i))α⋅ℓi​(S)<ℓi​(C(i)) for all i∈Si\in Si∈S. 111-core is the core.

If a group SSS exists that becomes a violation of the α\alphaα-core guarantee, we say that it deviates and refer to it as the deviating coalition.

🎯Theorem 1. For arbitrary losses, there exists an instance in which no α\alphaα-core clustering for any finite α\alphaα.

🎯Theorem 2. For the average loss, there exists an instance in which no α\alphaα-core clustering exists an instance in which no α\alphaα-core clustering exists for α<1+32≈1.366\alpha\lt\frac{1+\sqrt3}{2}\approx1.366α<21+3​​≈1.366.

❓Open problem 2: For the average loss, does there always exist a clustering in the α\alphaα-core for some constant α\alphaα?

GreedyCohesiveClustering Algorithm

It uses a subroutine A\mathcal AA, in which given a subset of agents N′⊆NN'\subseteq NN′⊆N, metric ddd, and threshold τ\tauτ, finds a cohesive cluster SSS.

The threshold τ\tauτ indicate the smallest size at which a group of agents deserve to form a cluster.

A\mathcal AA is SmallestAgentBall. It finds the smallest ball centered at agent that captures at least τ\tauτ agents, and returns a set of τ\tauτ agents from this ball.

  • Natural choice: τ=⌈n/k⌉\tau=\lceil n/k\rceilτ=⌈n/k⌉

So GreedyCohesiveClustering with SmallestAgentBall iteratively finds the smallest agent-centered ball containing ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉ agents and removes ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉ in that ball, until fewer than ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉ agents remain, at which point all remaining agents are put into one cluster and any remaining clusters are left empty.

Pseudo code for GreedyCohesiveClustering

Input: N,d,kN,d,kN,d,k

Output: kkk-clustering CCC

  2. j←1j\gets 1j←1 // current cluster member
  3. while N′≠∅N'\neq\emptyN′=∅ do
    • Cj←A(N′,d,⌈n/k⌉)C_j\gets\mathcal A(N',d,\lceil n/k\rceil)Cj​←A(N′,d,⌈n/k⌉) // find and remove the next cohesive cluster
    • N′←N′╲CjN'\gets N'\diagdown C_jN′←N′╲Cj​
    • j←j+1j\gets j+1j←j+1
  4. Cj,Cj+1,⋯ ,Ck←∅C_j,C_{j+1},\cdots,C_k\gets\emptyCj​,Cj+1​,⋯,Ck​←∅
  5. return C=(C1,⋯ ,Ck)C=(C_1,\cdots,C_k)C=(C1​,⋯,Ck​)

Pseudo code for SmallestAgentBall

Input: Subset of agent N′⊆N,d,τN'\subseteq N,d,\tauN′⊆N,d,τ

Output: a cluster SSS

  1. if ∣N′∣≤τ|N'|\le\tau∣N′∣≤τ then return S←N′S\gets N'S←N′
  2. if i∈N′i\in N'i∈N′ do
    • ℓi←τ\ell_i\gets\tauℓi​←τ-th closest agent in N′N'N′ to agent iii // arbitrarily broke the tie
    • ri←d(i,ℓi)r_i\gets d(i,\ell_i)ri​←d(i,ℓi​) // smallest ball centered at agent iii capturing at least τ\tauτ agents
  3. i∗←arg⁡min⁡i∈N′rii^*\gets\arg\min_{i\in N'}r_ii∗←argmini∈N′​ri​

Actually the GreedyCohesiveClustering is an adaptation of Greedy Capture by Chen et al. There are two key difference:

  1. Growing balls centered at the agents instead of all feasible candidate centers.
  2. Stop a ball as soon as it captures ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉ agents. While in GC, it continues.

🎯Theorem 3. For the average (resp. maximum) loss, the Greedy Capture algorithm is guaranteed to return a clustering in the (2⌈n/k⌉−3)(2\lceil n/k\rceil -3)(2⌈n/k⌉−3)-core (resp. 222-core) in O(kn)O(kn)O(kn) time complexity, and the bounds are tight.

Fully Justified Representation

Peters et al. introduced FJR as a relaxation of the core in the context of approval-based committee selection.

📖 Definition 2 (α\alphaα-FJR). For α≥1\alpha\ge1α≥1, a kkk-clustering CCC satisfies α\alphaα-FJR if there is no group of agents S⊆NS\subseteq NS⊆N with ∣S∣≥n/k|S|\ge n/k∣S∣≥n/k s.t. α⋅ℓi(S)<min⁡j∈Sℓj(C(j))\alpha\cdot\ell_i(S)\lt\min_{j\in S}\ell_j(C(j))α⋅ℓi​(S)<minj∈S​ℓj​(C(j)) for each i∈Si\in Si∈S, i.e., if α⋅max⁡i∈Sℓi(S)<min⁡j∈Sℓj(C(j))\alpha\cdot\max_{i\in S}\ell_i(S)\lt\min_{j\in S}\ell_j(C(j))α⋅maxi∈S​ℓi​(S)<minj∈S​ℓj​(C(j)). Trivially, ℓi(C(i))≥min⁡j∈Sℓj(C(j))\ell_i(C(i))\ge\min_{j\in S}\ell_j(C(j))ℓi​(C(i))≥minj∈S​ℓj​(C(j)).

Arbitrary Loss Functions

FJR clustering is guaranteed to exist even for arbitrary losses.

📖Definition 3 (most cohesive cluster). Given a set of agents NNN and a threshold τ\tauτ, the MostChesiveCluster problem asks to find a cluster S⊆NS\subseteq NS⊆N of size at least τ\tauτ s.t. the maximum loss of any i∈Si\in Si∈S for SSS is minimized, i.e., find arg⁡min⁡S⊆N′:∣S∣≥τmax⁡i∈Sℓi(S)\arg\min_{S\subseteq N':|S|\ge\tau}\max_{i\in S}\ell_i(S)argminS⊆N′:∣S∣≥τ​maxi∈S​ℓi​(S).

For λ≥1\lambda\ge1λ≥1, a λ\lambdaλ-approximate solution SSS satisfies λ⋅max⁡i∈Sℓi(S)≤max⁡i∈S′λi(S′)\lambda\cdot\max_{i\in S}\ell_i(S)\le\max_{i\in S'}\lambda_i(S')λ⋅maxi∈S​ℓi​(S)≤maxi∈S′​λi​(S′) for all S′⊆NS'\subseteq NS′⊆N with ∣S′∣≥τ|S'|\ge\tau∣S′∣≥τ, and a λ\lambdaλ-approx algorithm returns a λ\lambdaλ-approx solution on every instance.

If we plug in A\mathcal AA to the MostCohesiveCluster problem into GreedyCohesiveClustering algorithm yields λ\lambdaλ-FJR clustering.

🎯Theorem 4. For arbitrary losses, α≥1\alpha\ge1α≥1, and an α\alphaα-approximation algorithm A\mathcal AA for the MostCohesiveCluster problem, GreeedyCohesiveClustering is guaranteed to return a α\alphaα-FJR clustering. Hence, FJR is guaranteed to exist.

Proof omitted.

Average and Maximum Loss Functions

Let A∗\mathcal A^*A∗ be an exact ALG for the MostCohesiveCluster problem for the average loss.

It may run not in polynomial time. It can be used to detect whether a given undirected graph admits a clique of at least a given size (NP-Complete).

🤔Lemma 1. For the average (resp. maximum) loss, SmallestAgentBall is a 444-approximation (resp. 222-approximation) algorithm for the MostCohesiveCluster problem, and this is tight.

🤔Corollary 1. The Greedy Capture algorithm is guaranteed to return a clustering that is 444-FJR (resp. 222-FJR) for the average (resp. maximum) loss.

❓Open problem 3: For the average or maximum loss, what is the smallest α\alphaα for which an α\alphaα-FJR clustering can be computed in polynomial time, assuming P≠NPP\neq NPP=NP?

❓Open problem 4: What is the smallest α\alphaα s.t. there always exists a clustering that is simultaneously α\alphaα-FJR for both the average loss and the maximum loss?

Auditing FJR

Ideas used to find an approx FJR can also be used to audit the FJR approx of any given clustering.

📖Definition 4 (λ\lambdaλ-approx FJR auditing). A\mathcal AA is a λ\lambdaλ-approx FJR auditing algorithm, if given any clustering CCC, it returns θ\thetaθ s.t. the exact FJR approx of CCC is in [θ,λ⋅θ][\theta,\lambda\cdot\theta][θ,λ⋅θ].

🎯Theorem 5. For λ≥1\lambda\ge1λ≥1, if A\mathcal AA is a λ\lambdaλ-approx algorithm to the MostCohesiveCluster problem, then AuditFJR(A)(\mathcal A)(A) is a λ\lambdaλ-approx FJR auditing algorithm. Given lemma 1, it follows that for the average (resp. maximum) loss, AuditFJR(SmallestAgentBall) is an efficient 444-approx (resp. 222-approx) FJR auditing algorithm.

❓Open problem 5: Does there exist a polynomial time, α\alphaα-approx core auditing algorithm for some constant α\alphaα?

🎯Theorem 6. Assuming P≠NPP\neq NPP=NP, there does not exist a polynomial-time λ\lambdaλ-approx FJR auditing algorithm for the maximum loss, for any λ<2\lambda\lt2λ<2,

Experiments

Omitted

Discussion

Introduction to Proportional Fairness in Non-Centroid Clustering: This paper initiates the study of proportional fairness in non-centroid clustering and presents several open questions for further exploration.

Key Open Questions:

  • Achieving a better approximation than O(n/k)O(n/k)O(n/k) for the core concerning average loss.
  • Determining if the core is always non-empty for maximum loss.

Core Non-Emptiness Results:

  • Proven that the core is always non-empty for maximum loss in 1-dimensional metric spaces (Appendix C.1).
  • For average loss, however, the core remains empty even on the line (Appendix C.2).

Differences Between Clustering Settings:

  • Highlights significant distinctions between centroid and non-centroid clustering.

Future Directions:

  • Investigate proportional fairness guarantees when an agent’s loss depends on both their cluster center and other agents in their cluster.
  • Explore the possibility of intrinsically choosing the number of clusters kkk, which currently requires being fixed in advance for proportional fairness.

Compatibility with Classical Algorithms:

  • While traditional algorithms like kkk-means and kkk-centers may be incompatible with the core and FJR (Appendix E), studying conditions under which they might align with fairness criteria or can be efficiently computed is an interesting avenue.

My Initial Immature Idea

  4. return XXX

Idea is straightforward, directly eliminate 2-approx Block Coalition.

But how to continue, we need to rerun the Greedy Capture at some point.

Improve the Idea

Instead of using Greedy Capture as black box, we do some modification in it.

“Fine-tuning” Greedy Capture

In the while loop of Greedy Capture, we audit whether there exist 2-approx Block Coalition.

If there is one, we open the corresponding cluster center x∗x^*x∗, and fix all ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉ point in the Block Coalition.

Set the fixed radius rbcr_{bc}rbc​, denoting the distance from cluster center of BC to the ⌈n/k⌉\lceil n/k\rceil⌈n/k⌉-th nearest data point.

Open that cluster center.

Then run the Greedy Capture from the scratch neglecting all fixed point. We don’t synchronously increase rbcr_{bc}rbc​ until δ\deltaδ reaches rbcr_{bc}rbc​.

Also auditing the 2-approximate in that Greedy Capture, if there are block coalition related to any point in cluster x∗x^*x∗, we do the same recursively.

    • If δ\deltaδ for other surpass δx∗\delta_{x^*}δx∗​, increase δx∗\delta_{x^*}δx∗​ also.

    • while ∃x∈X\exist x\in X∃x∈X s.t. ∣B(x,δx)∩N∣≥1|B(x,\delta_x)\cap N|\ge1∣B(x,δx​)∩N∣≥1

      • N←N╲B(x,δx)N\gets N\diagdown B(x,\delta_x)N←N╲B(x,δx​)

    • while ∃x∈M╲X\exist x\in\mathcal M\diagdown X∃x∈M╲X s.t. ∣B(x,δx)∩N∣≥⌈n/k⌉|B(x,\delta_x)\cap N|\ge\lceil n/k\rceil∣B(x,δx​)∩N∣≥⌈n/k⌉ do

It is obvious that if the algorithm terminates, then we can find 2-approximate PROP clustering.

Running on the Example

On the example where no matter how the clustering is, the PROP approximation can not be better than 2. The algorithm exactly returns 2-PROP clustering.

On the example in which 1+21+\sqrt21+2​ is the lower bound for Greedy Capture, The algorithm returns exactly PROP clustering.
